1.b: Common laborers - wage earners - factory workers - all low income

areaDesc.8: This area is level to rolling with mixed population. Railroad belt line runs through eastern part of railroad yards join it in west. Some small industrial plants located on western side. Transportation and school facilities are adequate and negro high school located in area. Stores are also scattered through the area. Warner Park, largest in the city, joins at the southwest corner. There are some very nice small homes scattered throughout the area but the predominance is in the cheap, poorly maintained type. About half of the properties in the area have outside toilets, no bathrooms.     Sales activity is almost entirely in negro properties and is fair for them - but there is no demand for white properties.

1.b: Low income common laborers - domestics

areaDesc.8: The area is level to rolling, most of it outside city limits. Nearest transportation is about 4 blocks from the eastern line of the area. Houses are cheap, flimsy structures, very poorly maintained. It does not have either lights, water or sewerage. Colored school located in southern part of area. Some distance to central part of city and transportation not convenient.

1.b: Professional men - executives, white collar workers

areaDesc.8: The eastern part of the area is level to rolling and the western and southern part rolling to hilly. Transportation is by gasoline bus and is adequate. Houses are well constructed and well maintained. Schools are convenient, community business center not far distant and municipal golf course is very close to the northeast corner of the area. Area is about 50% improved. The area is in line with present development and because of relatively low land values, new construction activity has been very pronounced.

1.b: White collar workers - skilled mechanics, professional men

areaDesc.8: This area lies in North Chattanooga, across the river from Chattanooga proper and principal business district, but has all utilities and adequate transportation by gasoline bus. Grade and Jr. High School located in the area and a large community business center is located conveniently close. The area lies from rolling to hilly, maintenance of homes generally indicates pride of ownership. It is about 80% improved - receives a beneficial influence from the higher grade area to the north and east. Construction as a rule fairly substantial but some cheaper homes indicate lack of restrictions or failure to enforce them, especially in the section around Federal and Dartmouth Streets.

1.b: Low income industrial workers - mechanics and laborers

areaDesc.8: This area is rolling to hilly, one of the oldest sections in North Chattanooga. It has adequate transportation and school facilities and is convenient to the community business center of the section. There are several industrial plants south of the area, between it and the river.     It is an area of old cheaply built small houses, some shacks, and all very poorly maintained. Mixed type of low income population and cheapness and condiditon of properties make this a fourth grade area.

1.b: Workers on mountain - clerks - lower income white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This is a small area located on Signal Mountain, with benefit of high elevation. This development was originally for summer homes and construction was not substantial - hence improvement has ceased and there is hardly any promise for future improvement. Area is about 60% improved, schools, church, and community stores are convenient, and transportation is by gasoline bus and is adequate. Type of population and type of construction make it a third grade area.

1.e: During past 3 years there has been some infiltration of people with more moderate incomes.
1.b: Professional Men, executives, white collar workers

areaDesc.8: The area is located on Signal Mountain, a separate municipality about 7 miles from the Chattanooga business center. It has good grade school, community stores and adequate transportation by means of gasoline bus which runs from the mountain top to the center of Chattanooga on regular schedule. The mountain was developed by a wealthy Chattanooga man and formerly was used almost exclusively during the summer months by the moderately wealthy to wealthier Chattanooga residents. With very few exceptions type of houses built have been very substantial, some very costly, and residents now make the mountain their home for the entire year. A golf and country club is located on the mountain.     What formerly was a summer resort hotel was three years ago sold to the Alexian Brotherhood, a Catholic Organization, for use somewhat as a religious retreat and sanatorium. Some residents on the mountain claim that this has had no effect on the area from the standpoint of residential desirability, but the foot remains that there has been no new building in this area during the past three years, and while there is only one vacant house (Not including about 4 which are being repaired) rentals are about 65% of what they were 3 years ago and the only sales made have been at very low prices. With its high altitude, easy accessibility to the city, good type of population and good type of construction, it is still a very desirable place to live and will continue so, but the trend towards new building has veered to Lookout Mountain.

1.b: Skilled mechanics - white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This area lies outside city limits, is a level section, about 1/4 mile wide, lying between ridges on the east and west. Improvement on the east is largely concentrated to lots fronting Dayton Blvd. and is very scattered and of cheap construction towards the ridge on the east. Improvement on the west is more substantial and extends a distance of what would equal about 2 blocks away from Dayton Blvd. Between the city limits line and the southern boundary line of this beer taverns, some of which have a rather shady reputation.     On Dayton Blvd., just north of Midvale St., have recently been erected about 10 small 3 room houses, resembling tourist camps, all having the same appearance, on small lots that are about 3 feet below street elevation. Other new construction scattered throughout area but is not of any great proportion and is all in the low price class. Area has city water and electric lights but no gas or public sewerage.

1.b: White collar workers, minor executives, skilled mechanics.

areaDesc.8: This area located in Red Bank, outside Chattanooga city limits. It is in a valley with high ridges on both east and west sides. Both grade and high schools are located in the area, community business center is located on Dayton Boulevard and easily accessible to all parts of area. Transportation is by gasoline bus and is adequate. The center of the area (along Dayton Boulevard) is level with gradual rise to ridges to both east and west. Most substantial construction is along Dayton Boulevard and the section between the Boulevard and Lamar Avenue and Crisman and Morrison Springs Road. To the north of the area (not shown on the map) two subdivisions have been opened within past year and about 30 new homes built in price range $3000-4000. Being outside city limits, it is not burdened with city taxes but fire insurance rates are higher. Recent agitation has been started to create fire district to serve this area and Area C-2 just south of it in order to reduce fire insurance rates and provide better protection.

1.b: Professional men, executives, capitalists

areaDesc.8: The area if from rolling to hilly and only about 40% improved - the southern part (inside city limits) is the more thickly populated. The eastern part overlooks the Tennessee River, and it is in this section that the majority of the very high priced homes are located. The lower priced homes are located in the western part. Lots are large, well wooded and lawns well maintained, and as a rule homes are well designed.     The northern part (outside city limits) is sparsely improved. On Haywood Avenue, in the northwest corner of the area, a new subdivision has just been opened; 10 new homes have just been completed to sell for $5250-$5750. This building done by a speculative builder and his success with the first ten will govern his activity in the remainder of the subdivision which has approximately 100 lots. Part inside city limits served by bus - grade and junior high school are fairly convenient.     The extreme northern point of the area is only about 15 minutes by automobile from the central retail business section.

1.b: White collar workers - skilled mecahnics - some few professional men and minor executives

areaDesc.8: This area located in North Chattanooga just across the river from the principal business center of the city proper. Its contour is from rolling to very steep. On the south it joins a large community business center, has all utilities, schools and churches are convenient, and it has adequate transportation by gasoline bus. It is about the oldest section of North Chattanooga.     Age of properties, very hilly terrain, lower grade area on west and proximity to business center are features which adversely affect the desirability of the area, while on the contrary, its easy accessibility to the principal business center of the city proper is in its favor. Some properties are well maintained, others only fair and still others poorly maintained. The area is definitely on the down-grade and for this reason rates third class.

1.b: Hosiery Mill workers - mechanics - wage earners - laborers

areaDesc.8: The area lies level to rolling and hilly on the northern and eastern side which extends to Missionary Ridge. Has all utilities, grade and junior high school located in it, also churches and community business center. One of the larger hosiery mills of the city is located in this area and formerly provided employment to many of the inhabitants of the area, but a change in management of the mill has occurred in recent years and its activity has declined quite a bit. It now uses only about 60% of employees formerly used. As a whole the area is composed of cheaper constructed houses with little indication of any pride of home ownership.     Northern part of area not far from Chickamanga Dam and during construction of this dam, many of the workers resided in this area and it did not feel the effects of lessened activity of the hosiery mill. However, the dam is about complete and employment now is only about 40% of peak, and this will undoubtedly adversely affect this area within the next 6 months.

1.b: Business & professional men - white collar workers - salesmen

a.1: Old houses made into 2-4 fam. apts. 3-5 rms

areaDesc.8: This area is located in what is known as "Cameron Hill" a very high bluff overlooking the Tennessee River. It is within walking distance of the principal business center. Population in this area includes many Jews. It has all utilities, grade school is close as are churches and stores. Transportation is by gasoline bus and adequate.     This is a very old section, surrounded by lower grade areas on all sides, home ownership is declining yearly, many of the older inhabitants of the area moving to other sections.     Area is about 98% improved. The northern part is very hilly and southern part very rolling.

1.b: Laborers, domestics, low wage earners, some clerical

areaDesc.8: This area is level on the eastern side adjoining the main business district to rolling on the western side. White population is largely concentrated adjacent to area C-4, north of W. 9th St., and the greatest negro concentration is in the southeast and southwest part of the area. A colored low-rent housing project has been started on Main St. at College but will not be completed for about 12 months. It will contain 497 units.     The area as a whole consists of old, dilapidated houses, badly in need of repair, some few fairly good apartment houses. Schools and churches are in area and it adjoins principal business center.     Age of properties, lack of proper maintenance, type of population are such to make this a fourth grade area. Properties vary all the way from cheapest shacks occupied by negroes to large old brick houses now used as cheap rooming houses, some for white and some for colored.     About 5% of structures in this area are apartment houses containing 8-12 units of 2 to 4 rooms renting at about $15-$25 per month. They are old and not well maintained but proximity to principal business center keeps rental demand good

1.e: Gradual shifting to lower income group and rooming and boarding houses
1.b: Mechanics - white collar workers - wage earners

areaDesc.8: Area is from level to steeply rolling, about 98% improved, within easy walking distance of central business district, has all utilities, both street car and gasoline bus transportation, grade school in it and city high school at northeast corner. At the northwest corner on Bluff View are located about 10 large expensive homes still occupied by original owners, who are people of wealth and built these houses at this point because of the scenic view of the Tennessee River and the high elevation, but they are certainly misplaced. That part of the area east of Palmetto and from Oak St. to Fort Wood St. also contains some very large expensive homes, but the owners are trying to sell and can find no buyers. North, east and south are negro areas. Southern part of the area, Vine St., Oak St., and McCallis Avenue are filled with rooming and boarding houses (some good and some not so good) and also many apartment houses. It is just an old area, formerly occupied by people of means most all of whom have moved to other sections and left their large, fine old homes to be used as boarding or rooming houses or converted into apartments.

1.b: Some better class negro mechanics and also lower class negro laborers - domestics - some white clerical and wage earners

areaDesc.8: Part of the area north of McCallie is all negro except on McCallie and Oak east of Central Avenue. Some better negro properties on 5th St. off Central Avenue. Remainder of this part contains all kinds of negro properties with the bad predominating. Negro park at the northern corner of area. Railroad yards from the east boundary and noise and smoke is a nuissance. In that part of area south of McCallie, whites live in about 4 blocks from western side on 8th St. and negroes in other part of 8th to Central Ave. The principal negro business district of the city is located on E. 9th St. and negroes reside on it to Magnolia where whites reside on to Central Ave.     It is a mixed area of old houses, mixed population, poor maintenance, contour from rolling to hilly and about only thing in its favor is that it is within easy walking distance of main business center.     Schools, churches and stores are located in the area.     Sales activity almost exclusively in negro properties.

1.e: Infiltration of lower income group and exodus of former original owners of better income
1.b: White collar workers - skilled mechanics, tradesmen

areaDesc.8: This area is known as Highland Park, is level to rolling, has all utilities, grade and high schools located in it and also community stores especially along McCallie Avenue which is dotted with beer taverns, filling stations, and stores of every description. It is one of the older residential sections and one of the first suburban developments of original Chattanooga. It is convenient to the principal business district and transportation facilities are excellent. It is about 95% improved. The better part of the area is between Holly and Beech Streets, east and west, and Duveau and Kirby, north and south.     During depression years foreclosures were probably more in this section than anywhere else in the city and this fact together with infiltration of people of lower income has been the cause of declining prices. Accessibility to principal business section, proximity to Jackson Park and Warner Park, combine to make rental demand good in this area.

1.b: Factory workers, mechanics, white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This area is fairly level except on the eastern side which goes into the side of Missionary Ridge where it is rolling and hilly. It is composed of small single family homes occupied by people of lower incomes. Several industrial plants are located on Dodds Avenue between 23rd and 31st Streets. That part of the area west of 4th Avenue is low and subject to overflow from Chattanooga Creek in flood seasons. Transportation and school facilities are ample and stores are scattered throughout the area. Cheap construction, low income of population, and age of properties make this a third grade area. It is about 75% improved.     Bids have been received for the construction of a low-cost housing project in this area, located on 4th Avenue between 23rd and 28th Streets. It is to be constructed on a vacant tract of ground containing 35 acres and when completed will cost about $1,500,000, and provide about 437 new units.     Feger Place, consisting of Morningside Drive and Eveningside Drive, located in northwest corner of area, is a small subdivision containing about 25 homes originally costing $10,000 to $15,000. However, this has proved to be a misplaced development, the subdivision has lost its desirability due to unfavorable surroundings and properties can hardly be sold for in excess of 40% of original cost.

9.1: Forest Place - East Lake, Chattanooga, Tenn.

1.b: Low income industrial workers - mechanics and laborers

areaDesc.8: The entire area is level to rolling, the part north of 23rd Avenue being the most heavily populated and the section in which most of the negro population resides. Transportation and school facilities are adequate and this part of the area is easily accessible to the business district. Years ago it was occupied by railroad workers, firemen and policemen but in recent years an undesirable element of very low income people has gradually taken it over.     On 23rd St., east of Montague Park, is a tract of 16 acres on which is to be constructed a new National Guard Armory costing about $200,000. Work is expected to begin on this in the near future.     That part of the area south of 23rd St. is level, extending on both sides of Rossville Boulevard, the principal street leading out of the city to the south. Many beer taverns, filling stations, junk yards and other undesirable places are located on Rossville Blvd. It is also low and subject to overflow from water to Chattanooga Creek during high flood seasons.     Houses are small singles of every description, badly maintained, population is largely of the shiftless type. There are a few fairly good houses in the area, most of them widely scattered, with Crescent Circle and Clifton Terrace (in Clifton Hills) having the better houses.

1.e: Gradual infiltration of people of more moderate income when original owners die or move away
1.b: Professional, business men, executives, capitalists, some white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This area is the southern part of Missionary Ridge - located on the top of the Ridge with an elevation several hundred feet higher than the city proper. It is rolling, lots are rather large and well wooded. The northern 2/3 of the area contains the most expensive homes occupied by some of the wealthier citizens of the city. It has all utilities but no stores are located on the Ridge. All but about the southern 1/3 is served by street car. The northern 2/3 is about 90% improved while the southern 1/3 is only about 60% improved - the Ridge widens out at the southern end and there is more ground available for improvement than in the northern part. It is a delightful place on which to live but apparently reached the height of its popularity some time ago and while still desirable and will continue so for many years, the trend is away from it.

1.b: Professional men - executives - salesmen - white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This area known as the Glenwood Subdivision was opened about 15 years ago, was well planned and laid out with curving roadways. Construction at the outset was of a rather high type but in more recent years some cheaper homes were built. It is level except towards the east which is rolling and extends into Missionary Ridge, but there are only a few improved lots on this side. Grade school located in area and only short distance to high school. Area has all utilities and adequate bus transportation - it is also only about 10 minutes drive to the principal business center. Generally, homes are well kept and there are indications of pride of ownership. Area only about 50% improved. For some reason it has stopped growing.

1.e: Present trend is to persons of more moderate income
1.b: Professional men - executives - better income bracket

areaDesc.8: This area is the northern part of Missionary Ridge. It has a very high elevation, is only wide enough on top for one street which in some parts has houses on both sides and in others the street runs along the side of the ridge and houses are therefore only on one side of the street. The sides of the ridge, except in a few spots, are too steep for building purposes. Area has all utilities, adequate street car transportation, grade school, but no stores are located on the ridge, but are not far distant. It is about 4 miles from the principal business center. Major portion of construction has been of the very expensive type but no new homes have recently been constructed. Originally it was occupied by the wealthier citizens of the city but in recent years they have been moving away and their homes are either being rented or sold at sacrifice prices. Available building sites are about 70% improved.

1.b: Business & professional men - executives - white collar workers, skilled mechanics and some wage earners.

areaDesc.8: This area lies east of Missionary Ridge and is reached by a tunnel through the ridge. It consists of East Highlands and a part of the Brainerd Section. It is rolling to hilly, is thickly wooded, lots are wide, schools and churches are located in the area, and there is quite an extensive community business center on Brainerd Road just after passing through the tunnel under the Ridge. Brainerd Road is dotted with tourist homes, filling stations, taverns, and is gradually going to business although there are some very substantial homes located on it but mostly towards the eastern end. Area has all utilities and adequate transportation by gasoline bus.     The East Highlands section is all outside the city limits and while it has all utilities and adequate transportation, type of construction is not as substantial as in the remainder of the area, and it is in this part of the area that the lower period properties are located and the lower income group of people live. Area as a whole is about 75% improved.

1.b: Professional men and executives with good incomes

areaDesc.8: This area is rolling, lots are wide, well maintained and well wooded. Construction is uniform and homes well designed. It is well restricted and restrictions have been more rigidly enforced than in any other section of the city. It is located outside the city limits but is served by gasoline bus and has city fire protection. The area is about 40% improved. Convenient to community business center on Brainerd Road.     Type of construction is good and maintenance of homes and lawns indicates high type of home ownership. The subdivision is so laid out to add charm and appeal. Northern part of area along Shallowford Road slopes rather steeply and this slope continues across the road, making building sites not as desirable, and no restrictions as to building are in effect - hence the jump from 1st to 3rd grade.

1.b: Skilled mechanics, white collar workers

areaDesc.8: The area is very rolling, about 40% improved, but is handicapped by lack of uniformity. There are some very cheap properties located in it especially in the southern part. It has adequate transportation facilities. Schools are convenient as well as stores but churches somewhat distant.     Presence of cheap construction and poor maintenance and mixture of type of popuation make this a third grade area.

1.b: Low income, industrial workers - mechanics - laborers

areaDesc.8: This is one of the very old sections of the city, level and about 80% improved. Many industrial plants are located west of Broad St. and just south of the area. Transportation and school facilities are adequate and stores of every description abound on Broad St., the western boundary, and Main Street, the northern boundary. Age of properties, lack of maintenance, mixture and type of population make this a fourth grade area.

1.b: White collar workers - employees of Chattanooga Medicine Company, mechanics

areaDesc.8: This section is known as St. Elmo. It is located at the base of Lookout Mountain and contour generally is from rolling to very hilly. Community business center is located in the north end of the area. Transportation and school facilities are adequate. Plant of Chattanooga Medicine Company located at north end of area provides employment to many residents of the area.     It is one of the older communities and its residents do not often move out of it, and on the contrary, it does not attract residents from other communities. It is some distance from the principal business center and the approach to the center of the city is through one of the worst sections of the city.

1.b: Factory workers - mechanics - clerks

areaDesc.8: This is a level area, formerly Alton Park. Before it was annexed to Chattanooga every street in it was paved with concrete. Nearby and in the area are located plants of Armour & Company, Wilson & Company, a brick yard, and Chattanooga Glass Factory, which provide employment for many residents of the area.     Transportation and school facilities are adequate and several small stores are located in the area. Some distance to principal business center.     Area about 60% improved.     Presence of railraod tracks through area, industrial plants, cheap construction and low income of residents make this a third grade area.

1.b: Professional men, executives, some white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This area is located on top of Lookout Mountain, a separate municipality about 6 miles from the center of Chattanooga. It is served by 2 paved highways, also by an Incline Railway and gasoline bus from the railway terminus on top of the mountain. It has an elevation of 2200 feet and is especially delightful in the summer. This area is on the "inside" and does not include the sites overlooking the brow on either side, and therefore does not have the scenic advantages of the brow sites. For this reason, home as a whole are not as expensive as those located in the brow sites and construction is not quite as substantial.     Terrain is rolling, lots are large and well wooded. Schools, churches, and stores are located in the area. Presence of small negro population is caused by the fact that they were brought to the mountain to work as domestics for the white population. There are about forty of these negro houses, mostly owned by the occupants, they range in value from $1000 to $2000 and of course, are not worthy of second grade, but these houses are somewhat scattered and there are not sufficient of them in one spot to make a separate area.

1.b: Business & professional men - executives - capitalists.

areaDesc.8: This area is located on Lookout Mountain and includes both East Brow and West Brow, which overlook the country for miles around, and on which many beautiful and costly homes have been built. Formerly the mountain was used almost entirely for summer homes for wealthy people of Chattanooga, but in later years most of the inhabitants have been staying on the mountain the entire year. While some of the houses were built as summer homes the great majority are of good construction, well planned and well maintained.     It is a seperate municipality, about 6 miles from Chattanooga business center. There are two principal highways from Chattanooga to the top of the mountain and it is also served by an Incline Railway (in use about 40 years) from the base to the top, and gasoline bus also serves the locality on top of the mountain. Its elevation is about 2200 feet, which is about 1600 feet higher than Chattanooga proper, and it is a delightful place in which to live. It also has quite a historic background.     Its popularity has increased considerably during the past three years. The present trend to the mountain, the type of population, construction of majority of homes, and its desirability as a residential spot make it a first grade area.
